content.text: On Figs. 1.1 and 1.2, measure the height \(h\), width \(w\) and depth \(d\) of the block
On Fig. 1.2, draw the line \(\mathbf{AC}\)
Measure and record the angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{AD}\) and \(\mathbf{AC}\)
A student places the block on the edge of the bench, as shown in Fig. 1.3
He holds the protractor next to face **ABCD** of the block, as shown in Fig. 1.3. He gently pushes the top of the block (as indicated in Fig. 1.3) so that the block tips over

He records the angle \(\theta\) between side \(\mathbf{BC}\) of the block and the vertical line on the protractor. The angle \(\theta\) is when the block just tips over. He repeats this procedure a suitable number of times
Suggest the number of measurements of \(\theta\) that you think would be suitable for this experiment
The student calculates the average value \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\) of all his values for \(\theta\)
He suggests that \(\theta_{\mathrm{av}}\) should be equal to \(\alpha\). State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your statement by reference to the results

justification
The IGCSE class is investigating the stability of a block of wood
Figs. 1.1 and 1.2 show the dimensions of the block
Fig. 1.2
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) as shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1
A student pours hot water into a beaker. She measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the beaker every 30 s. The readings are shown in Table 2.1
Using Fig. 2.2, measure, and record in the table, the distance \(d\) from the end of the thermometer to the position of the liquid in the thermometer at the first temperature reading in the table
Fig. 2.2
Repeat the measurement in (b)(i) for all the other temperature readings
Complete the column headings in the table
Explain how the graph line shows that \(\theta\) is not directly proportional to \(d\)
Suggest why, when \(\theta = 0^\circ \mathrm{C}\), the value of \(d\) is not zero
The student plotted a graph of \(\theta\) against \(d\). A sketch of the graph obtained is shown in Fig. 2.3

Repeat step (i) for each of the other values of x
Complete the column headings in the table

The student pushes two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) into this line. She views the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1

She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and \(\mathsf{P}_3\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), all appear exactly one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are labelled

Draw in the line joining the positions \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Continue the line until it extends at least \(8.0 \text{cm}\) beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\)
Label with a \(\mathbf{Y}\) the point where the two lines beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\) cross

Use these results to calculate an average value for the mass of \(\mathbf{X}\) and give it to a suitable number of significant figures for this type of experiment

way to overcome the difficulty
The IGCSE class is determining the mass of a load \(\mathbf{X}\) using a balancing method
